articles.headline: Shortage of Artillery Ammunition Saps Ukrainian Frontline Morale
articles.snippet: Shells for Soviet-era weapons are running short, and powerful Western weapons are not arriving fast enough to make up the difference, giving Russia a big advantage in artillery.
articles.abstract: Shells for Soviet-era weapons are running short, and powerful Western weapons are not arriving fast enough to make up the difference, giving Russia a big advantage in artillery.
articles.lead_paragraph: DONETSK REGION, Ukraine — Nearly four months after Russia invaded, the Ukrainian military is running low on ammunition for its Soviet-era artillery and has not received enough supplies from its allies to keep the Russians at bay, Ukrainian officials and artillery officers in the field say.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Andrew E. Kramer and Natalia Yermak

articles.headline: McDonald’s Is Back, Moscow Style, as Russian Economy Stumbles On
articles.snippet: The reopening of the fast-food stores under Russian ownership (and with a new logo) illustrates the economy’s surprising resilience in the face of intense sanctions, though tough times lie ahead.
articles.abstract: The reopening of the fast-food stores under Russian ownership (and with a new logo) illustrates the economy’s surprising resilience in the face of intense sanctions, though tough times lie ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yevgeny Shumilkin is going back to work on Sunday. To prepare, he pulled the familiar “M” off what had been his McDonald’s shirt and covered the “M” on his McDonald’s jacket with a Russian flag patch.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

articles.headline: Ocasio-Cortez Turns a New York Brawl Into a National Democratic Proxy Battle
articles.snippet: By endorsing her colleague’s primary challenger, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has escalated a skirmish rippling beyond New York.
articles.abstract: By endorsing her colleague’s primary challenger, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has escalated a skirmish rippling beyond New York.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sean Patrick Maloney is a Democratic Party stalwart who declares himself a “practical, mainstream guy.”

articles.headline: Jan. 6 Panel Puts Focus on Cabinet Discussions About Removing Trump
articles.snippet: Other reports verify Representative Liz Cheney’s assertion that cabinet members considered using the 25th Amendment to oust Donald Trump after the assault on the Capitol.
articles.abstract: Other reports verify Representative Liz Cheney’s assertion that cabinet members considered using the 25th Amendment to oust Donald Trump after the assault on the Capitol.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Representative Liz Cheney asserted at the House Jan. 6 hearing on Thursday that Trump administration cabinet members weighed invoking the constitutional process to remove President Donald J. Trump from office after the attack on the Capitol by his supporters, she did not immediately provide details or evidence.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Why We Still Haven’t Solved the Unpaid Internship Problem
articles.snippet: Unpaid internships benefit schools and employers, but aren’t fair to college students footing their own tuition bills.
articles.abstract: Unpaid internships benefit schools and employers, but aren’t fair to college students footing their own tuition bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: The president and vice president announced this month that they were going to pay their interns. The White House put out a news release. I think we were supposed to stand up and cheer.

articles.headline: Should Biden Run in 2024? Democratic Whispers of ‘No’ Start to Rise.
articles.snippet: In interviews, dozens of frustrated Democratic officials, members of Congress and voters expressed doubts about the president’s ability to rescue his reeling party and take the fight to Republicans.
articles.abstract: In interviews, dozens of frustrated Democratic officials, members of Congress and voters expressed doubts about the president’s ability to rescue his reeling party and take the fight to Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Midway through the 2022 primary season, many Democratic lawmakers and party officials are venting their frustrations with President Biden’s struggle to advance the bulk of his agenda, doubting his ability to rescue the party from a predicted midterm trouncing and increasingly viewing him as an anchor that should be cut loose in 2024.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Jennifer Medina

articles.headline: Here’s What You Need to Know About America’s Super-Hot Inflation
articles.snippet: Inflation is a tricky problem, but it has a few clear causes and consequences, and policymakers are working to bring it to heel.
articles.abstract: Inflation is a tricky problem, but it has a few clear causes and consequences, and policymakers are working to bring it to heel.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government reported on Friday that consumer prices climbed 8.6 percent over the year through May, the fastest rate of increase in four decades.

articles.headline: Why Students Are Choosing H.B.C.U.s: ‘4 Years Being Seen as Family’
articles.snippet: Many in a generation that grew up with a Black president and Black Lives Matter are embracing Black colleges and universities.
articles.abstract: Many in a generation that grew up with a Black president and Black Lives Matter are embracing Black colleges and universities.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Jan. 6 Committee Appears to Lay Out Road Map for Prosecuting Trump
articles.snippet: The first prime-time hearing into the Jan. 6 attack confronted the fundamental question that has haunted Donald J. Trump since he left office: Should he be prosecuted in a criminal court?
articles.abstract: The first prime-time hearing into the Jan. 6 attack confronted the fundamental question that has haunted Donald J. Trump since he left office: Should he be prosecuted in a criminal court?
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the House committee hearing on the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Katie Benner

articles.headline: They Inhabited Separate Worlds in Taiwan. Decades Later, They Collided in a California Church.
articles.snippet: The 68-year-old suspect in a May mass shooting harbored resentment dating back to his formative years in Taiwan.
articles.abstract: The 68-year-old suspect in a May mass shooting harbored resentment dating back to his formative years in Taiwan.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Chou and Pastor Billy Chang spent their whole lives forging parallel paths. They were born in early 1950s Taiwan, grew up just miles apart during martial law and later rebuilt their lives in the United States.
articles.byline: By Amy Qin, Jill Cowan, Shawn Hubler and Amy Chang Chien

articles.headline: Poland Shows the Risks for Women When Abortion Is Banned
articles.snippet: Poland’s abortion ban has had many unintended consequences. One is that doctors are sometimes afraid to remove fetuses or administer cancer treatment to save women’s lives.
articles.abstract: Poland’s abortion ban has had many unintended consequences. One is that doctors are sometimes afraid to remove fetuses or administer cancer treatment to save women’s lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Monika Pronczuk

articles.headline: Senators Reach Bipartisan Deal on Gun Safety
articles.snippet: The agreement, which falls short of the sprawling changes championed by Democrats, is a significant step toward ending a yearslong impasse over gun reform legislation.
articles.abstract: The agreement, which falls short of the sprawling changes championed by Democrats, is a significant step toward ending a yearslong impasse over gun reform legislation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the Senate vote on the bipartisan gun control bill.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Annie Karni

articles.headline: Bolsonaro’s New Ally in Questioning Brazil’s Elections: The Military
articles.snippet: Despite little evidence of past fraud, President Jair Bolsonaro has long raised doubts about Brazil’s electoral process. Now the military is expressing similar concerns.
articles.abstract: Despite little evidence of past fraud, President Jair Bolsonaro has long raised doubts about Brazil’s electoral process. Now the military is expressing similar concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil has for months consistently trailed in the polls ahead of the country’s crucial presidential race. And for months, he has consistently questioned its voting systems, warning that if he loses October’s election, it will most likely be thanks to a stolen vote.

articles.headline: Tough Questions for West as Ukraine Cities Teeter
articles.snippet: Sievierodonetsk is nearly encircled. Lysychansk may be next. The momentum of the war has shifted, and Ukraine’s allies may soon start rethinking their goals.
articles.abstract: Sievierodonetsk is nearly encircled. Lysychansk may be next. The momentum of the war has shifted, and Ukraine’s allies may soon start rethinking their goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — With Russia about to encircle Sievierodonetsk, a city critical to its goal of seizing Ukraine’s east, and with a neighboring city squarely in Moscow’s sights, the question of how realities on the ground will shape the next phase of the war became still more pressing Sunday for Ukraine’s Western allies.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

articles.headline: India’s Economy Is Growing Quickly. Why Can’t It Produce Enough Jobs?
articles.snippet: The disconnect is a result of India’s uneven growth, powered and enjoyed by the country’s upper strata.
articles.abstract: The disconnect is a result of India’s uneven growth, powered and enjoyed by the country’s upper strata.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On paper, India’s economy has had a banner year. Exports are at record highs. Profits of publicly traded companies have doubled. A vibrant middle class, built over the past few decades, is now shelling out so much on movie tickets, cars, real estate and vacations that economists call it post-pandemic “revenge spending.”
articles.byline: By Emily Schmall and Sameer Yasir

articles.headline: How Covid Did Away With the Sick Day
articles.snippet: Some workers have no choice but to clock in. Others find the flexibility of remote work leads them to log in from their sick beds.
articles.abstract: Some workers have no choice but to clock in. Others find the flexibility of remote work leads them to log in from their sick beds.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tone of the typical isolation postcard is sunny, insistent and aspirational as a holiday greeting: “Thanks to everyone who sent well wishes for @VP,” wrote Doug Emhoff, the second gentleman, on Twitter. “She is feeling good and is working from home.”

articles.headline: Bear Market Sends Grim Signal of Economic Fears
articles.snippet: The S&P has declined 22 percent since January, amid converging worries about inflation, the Ukraine war, Covid and the Fed’s response to the economy.
articles.abstract: The S&P has declined 22 percent since January, amid converging worries about inflation, the Ukraine war, Covid and the Fed’s response to the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three weeks ago, Wall Street narrowly escaped a bear market, with stocks rebounding at the last minute from a brutal drop that had brought the S&P 500 down 20 percent from a record high in January. The next few weeks offered a glimmer of hope that the worst of the losses might be over.
articles.byline: By Mohammed Hadi and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: As China Rattles Sabers, Taiwan Asks: Are We Ready for War?
articles.snippet: Ukraine’s stubborn resistance to invasion, and the help that has poured in as a result, has both inspired Taiwan and made it rethink its own military strategy.
articles.abstract: Ukraine’s stubborn resistance to invasion, and the help that has poured in as a result, has both inspired Taiwan and made it rethink its own military strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Russia’s brutal war in Ukraine has jolted Taiwan into confronting the specter of a sudden attack from the island’s own larger and more powerful neighbor: China.
articles.byline: By Amy Qin, Amy Chang Chien and Lam Yik Fei
